title: 6 Behavioral Nudges to Reduce Bias in Hiring and Promotions
description: everyone who has worked to get diversity right knows there is no elixir that increases diverse talent in leadership roles. Doing DEI by the numbers just won’t get you there. But here’s some good news: By focusing on decision intelligence, and on evidence-based solutions that drive scalable change and increase inclusion, leaders can increase the number of diverse candidates that they hire and promote.

title: How to reduce bias in your workplace
description: We all have bias -- especially the unconscious kind -- and it's preventing us from doing our best work. Gone unchecked, bias can make employees feel resentful, frustrated and silenced, and it can even lead to outright discrimination and harassment. Check out three key ways to reduce bias at work, according to Just Work cofounders Kim Scott and Trier Bryant.

title: A New Way to Combat Bias at Work
description: Joan Williams says that it's extremely difficult for organizations to rid their workforces of the unconscious biases that can prevent women and minorities from advancing. But it's not so hard for individual managers to interrupt bias within their own teams. She offers specific suggestions for how bosses can shift their approach in four areas: hiring, meetings, assignments, and reviews/promotions.

title: What Makes an Inclusive Leader
description: Organizational leaders are increasingly leveraging inclusion to attract talent, retain employees, and motivate high creativity and excellence.

title: Inclusive Leadership Training
description: A programme designed to equip leaders with the mindset and skills needed to create workplaces where every individual feels valued, respected, and empowered to contribute. Through practical tools, self-awareness, and real-world strategies, participants learn to embrace diversity, foster psychological safety, and lead with empathy and equity — building stronger, more innovative, and more inclusive teams.

title: Belonging circles
description: A supportive space designed for managers to come together, discuss challenges, and share experiences. Leading a team brings unique rewards and responsibilities, and we recognize that navigating these can sometimes be challenging. Belonging Circles offer a place to connect with fellow managers, exchange insights, and learn strategies to support each other and foster belonging within our teams.

title: What First-Time managers Can Do to Address Burnout
description: Becoming “the boss” is a significant career transition, and is often accompanied by shifting relationship dynamics at work, including leading direct reports. If managers don’t put their mental health first, burnout could easily rub off onto their teams. Here are some ways to take care of yourself as you start to lead.

title: Leading the 6-Generation Workforce
description: Explores how today’s leaders can navigate and leverage the most age-diverse workforce in history. It offers insights into understanding generational differences, fostering collaboration across age groups, and creating inclusive environments where every generation’s strengths contribute to collective success.

title: 12 top leaders share how they are redefining leadership to embrace inclusivity
description: As the next generation of leaders emerges and matures, it is imperative that we redefine leadership models to ensure they are inclusive and accessible to all. This Articleexplores the emergence of this new leadership paradigm through the work of visionary Young Global Leaders who are championing change in various fields.

title: The Manager’s Guide to Inclusive Leadership — Small Habits That Make a Big Impact
description: Explores how everyday actions can help managers build more inclusive and equitable teams. It highlights practical, simple habits that foster trust, belonging, and psychological safety, showing how small, consistent changes in leadership behavior can create meaningful and lasting impact.

title: Are You Playing Favorites With Employee Recognition?
description: A common misconception shared by managers and leaders is that paychecks alone are enough to make employees feel valued. While paychecks are still important, real value is best conveyed by recognizing employees for who they are and what they do. Employee recognition engages, retains and develops employees.

title: Is Your Employee Recognition Really Authentic?
description: Employees want -- and need -- to be recognized at work for what they do and who they are. Gallup and Workhuman have uncovered many ways in which recognition boosts employees’ engagement, wellbeing, inclusion and belonging at work -- all of which may help to explain why organizations that make recognition a part of their culture also see cost-savings in retention.

title: It’s not about the office, it’s about belonging
description: To retain employees, organizations need to evolve their approach to building community, cohesion, and a sense of belonging at work.

title: What Is Psychological Safety?
description: Explores the concept of psychological safety — a team environment where people feel safe to speak up, share ideas, admit mistakes, and ask questions without fear of embarrassment or punishment. It highlights why psychological safety is crucial for learning, innovation, and performance, clarifies common misconceptions, and offers practical ways leaders can foster a culture of trust, openness, and inclusion at work.

title: Diversity and Inclusion: Bottom-Up as Well as Top-Down
description: Highlights how lasting diversity and inclusion require both top-down leadership commitment and bottom-up employee engagement, showing that real progress happens when strategy and grassroots action work together.

title: Women in the Workplace 2024
description:
Over the past decade, there have been important gains for women at every level of the corporate pipeline, particularly in senior leadership. Almost 30% of C-suite leaders are now women.
